message.content: This question requires a basic understanding of the states of matter. A solid has a fixed shape, meaning it maintains its shape regardless of its container. When a liquid is boiled and turns into a gas, it changes its shape and fills the entire container it is in. This change in shape from a fixed shape to an impermanent shape is why option (A), impermanent, is the correct answer. Options (B), (C), and (D) are unrelated and do not describe the change in shape during the state change from liquid to gas.

This question tests understanding of the physical properties of solids, liquids, and gases. When a liquid is boiled and turns into a gas, its shape becomes impermanent. Gas particles are not confined to a fixed shape and can expand to fill the space available to them. Option (B), (C), and (D) are unrelated to the physical properties of substances.

This question requires basic knowledge of the three states of matter. When a liquid is boiled and turns into a gas, its shape becomes impermanent. In the gaseous state, the particles are free to move and spread out, taking the shape of their container or filling the available space. Option (B) is unrelated to the question and incorrect. Options (C) and (D) are random and unrelated to the concept of states of matter.

This question requires basic knowledge about the states of matter and their properties. A solid has a fixed shape, which means it does not change its shape under normal conditions. When a liquid is boiled and turns into a gas, its shape becomes impermanent because gases do not have a fixed shape. Option (B) is unrelated to the question and not a property of gases. Options (C) and (D) are also unrelated to the question and not properties of any state of matter.

This question requires basic knowledge of the states of matter and how they change. A solid has a fixed shape, meaning it maintains a specific shape and volume. When a liquid is boiled and turns into a gas, its shape becomes impermanent. This means that it does not have a fixed shape, but rather takes on the shape of its container or expands to fill the available space. Options (B), (C), and (D) are unrelated to the change of state from a liquid to a gas.
